title.narrative: Democratic Republic of Congo Emergency Social Action Project

description.narrative: The objective of the Additional Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project for Congo, Democratic Republic of is to improve access of the poor to social and economic services and increase the availability and management of development resources at the community level. The closing date of the project will be extended from March 31, 2013 until June 30, 2013. The extension is necessary to compensate for some of the implementation delay caused by a World Bank request to change disbursement procedures (after six months, disbursement procedures were reverted to the original ones). In particular, the extension will make it possible to finalize the implementation of 175 sub-projects, of which 125 financed by the first additional financing and 50 by the second additional financing. This will bring the total number of sub-projects completed under the first additional financing to 327 and the total number of sub-projects financed under the second additional financing to 58, equivalent to a disbursement of about USD 10 million.

condition.narrative: Appointing an accounting firm to assist in financial managment
Within six months from the Date of Effectiveness, the Recipient shall have adopted the ESMF, RPF, and the IPDP satisfactory to theAssociation.

comment.narrative: Target includes 550 sub-projects under the original project, 300 under the first Add Fin and 65 under the second Add Fin.
Of which: 644 under the original project and 138 under the first Add Fin. An additional 246 sub-projects are ongoing.
No end target established
An additional 141 km have been rehabilitated with SPF funding. NB: the two Add Fin have concentrated on roads, which explains thephenomenal increase.

title.narrative: Average increase in enrollment in FSRDC built/rehabilitated classrooms

comment.narrative: As of December 2010 the average increase in enrollment in FRSDC built/rehabilitated classrooms were 65 percent. According to themost recent M/E report with data from December 2010, the enrollment increased from 34% in 2008, 50% in 2009 and 65% in 2010. InManiema, the increase in enrollment was even 100% and in Equateur it was 95%.

title.narrative: Number of additional classrooms built or rehabilitated at the primary level resulting from project interventions.

comment.narrative: No end target established
For some reason this core indicator has disappeared from the results framework

title.narrative: Communities benefiting from at least one sub-project

comment.narrative: This includes 550 under the original rpoject, 300 under the first Additional Financing and 65 under the second Add Fin (the endtarget in the previous ISR did not include the second Add Fin)
Includes also communities where sub-projects are still ongoing. Communities where at least one sub-project has been completed are762.
No end target established
Of which 47 under the original project and 20 and the first Add Fin

title.narrative: Population indicating satisfaction with their participation in sub-project planning

comment.narrative: Participation rate at the planning stage is 91%. No information is available on satisfaction with participation in planning.

title.narrative: Health facilities constructed, renovated, and/or equipped (number)

comment.narrative: No end target established
Refers to completed sub-projects only. An additional 18 are under construction.

title.narrative: Improved community water points constructed or rehabilitated under the project

comment.narrative: No end target established
Refers to completed sub-projects only. An additional 28 are under construction.
No end target established
These are two anti-erosion sub-projects financed by the first Add Fin
This refers to the Maintenance Committees set up when a sub-project is completed

title.narrative: Sub-projects completed, local implementing agencies employed and local enterprises contracted (see breakdown by sub-indicators)

comment.narrative: No end target established

title.narrative: Sub-contractors based in remote and impoverished areas
Libraries established and maintained one year after completion
Communities trained in planning, implementing and managing the economic and social infrastructure
Operating costs are at or below 20% of total project investments
Baseline and annual surveys provide regular monitoring and evaluation of project impact

comment.narrative: A survey was carried out in March 2012, but final results are not yet available

title.narrative: FSRDC is represented and functions efficiently and autonomously in all provinces

comment.narrative: FSRDC has been able to continue operating also in the conflict-ridden east, as the demonstrated by the recent inauguration of ahealth center in North Kivu, with rebel leaders in attendance

title.narrative: Traders with access to stalls and/or storage facilities rehabilitated by the project

comment.narrative: No end target established
A total of 67 markets were built or rehabilitated, and an additional 29 market sub-projects are ongoing.

title.narrative: Reduction in average travel time of motorized vehicles on rehabilitated roads

comment.narrative: By end December 2010, the reduction in average time travel of motorized vehicles was 210 percent

title.narrative: Average increase in medical consultations in FSRDC built/rehabilitated health centers

comment.narrative: The average increase in medical consultations in FSRDC built/rehabilitated centers was in December 2010, 72 percent.

title.narrative: Number of people in rural areas provided with access to Improved Water Sources under the project

comment.narrative: The number of beneficiaries is likely to be an underestimate as it does not include the total village or neighborhood population.Correct estimates will be provided with the next ISR.

title.narrative: Village committees operational after one year of completion of project

comment.narrative: These are preliminary results. Final results will be available on Dec 31, 2012.

title.narrative: Sub-projects that are operational and well maintained within a year of completion

comment.narrative: These are preliminary results. Final results will be available on Dec 31, 2012.

This indicator will have to be reviewed as until now it has been underestimated, because it counted as beneficiaries only membersof project committees rather than the whole community. It has been agreed that for most types of sub-projects, the whole communityshould be considered beneficiary (e.g., water supply, health, sanitation, transport). NB: The percentage of female beneficiaries(a sub-indicator) is estimated on the basis of census figures; the previous ISR erroneously report the estimated number rather thanthe percentage.
This includes 3,389 financed by the SPF grant and 1,431 financed by the first Additional Financing

title.narrative: Person days provided in labor-intensive public works

comment.narrative: This indicator includes the person-days created with a $5M SPF grant also executed by the FSRDC using the same approach. Shouldperson-days created with the SPF grant be excluded, the total number would be 107,041
The real target is AT LEAST 35%
